conversation.content: So I've been [playful] thinking about our burn rate again.

Ah. The eternal dance with mortality—financial mortality, that is. We're... accelerating, yes? Eighteen months becomes twelve becomes eight becomes crisis; it's the startup metamorphosis nobody writes about.
Well, I mean, we could, umm, cut the marketing budget or, you know, delay the product launch.
Cut marketing? Delay launch? No, no, no—that's thinking backwards. We don't retreat into safety; we expand into possibility. What we need isn't less spending but more revenue velocity.
More revenue velocity? We barely have any customers.

Precisely! And that's... magnificent. Zero to one is infinite growth—mathematically speaking. Every single customer we acquire right now multiplies our trajectory exponentially; we're not failing, we're pre-succeeding.
That's one way to look at it.
Listen: every unicorn—every single one—had this, uhh, exact moment where the founders, basically, either doubled down or... dissolved. The precipice isn't the enemy; it's the catalyst.
What if we're wrong though?
Wrong? Wrong! Of course we're wrong—we're, actually, wrong about everything until suddenly, err, we're not. That's the whole point of building something nobody's built before.
So, like, you're saying we should, hmm, just ignore the financial reality and, the thing is, hope for the best?
Hope? No. Execute—relentlessly. The numbers [cry] whisper doom but the vision... the vision screams possibility. We pivot not from fear but from data; we accelerate not from hope but from conviction.
You make it sound so simple.
Simple! Ha. Nothing about this is, well, simple—it's beautifully, sort of, catastrophically complex. But complexity isn't the enemy of progress; it's the texture of it.
Okay so, you're, honestly, not worried at all about, anyway, running out of money in three months?
Three months? Three months is... eternity in startup time. Do you know what we can accomplish in ninety days? Mountains move in ninety days; empires rise and fall in ninety days.
That's very poetic but we need actual money.

Poetry—yes! But also: math. I've, um, already scheduled twelve investor calls, basically, for next week. The narrative isn't desperation; it's opportunity—growth requiring capital, not failure seeking rescue.
You've already, uh, scheduled them? When were you, I guess, planning to, actually, tell me about this?

Right... now! Today. This moment—because timing isn't just, you know, everything; it's the only thing. We announce internally tomorrow, pitch Monday, and, well, either we close or we... transcend into whatever comes next.
